Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation2: During a casual networking event, someone casually asks about the nature of a client’s case.
Story: Tonight was supposed to be ours. My boyfriend and I had circled this date on the calendar weeks ago, knowing it was the only evening we’d have together before I left for a week-long trial. He wanted to make it special—dinner at our favorite place, just us, no distractions. But as we walked in, I spotted a few colleagues at the bar, and before I knew it, we were swept into a group conversation. One of them, half-joking, asked about the high-profile case I was working on. My boyfriend’s eyes sparkled with curiosity; he’d always wanted to know more about my work, and here was his chance to hear something firsthand. I felt the weight of their expectations—his desire to feel included in my world, my colleagues’ casual camaraderie, and my own professional obligation to keep my client’s secrets. My heart pounded as I tried to laugh it off, but inside, I was torn. I wanted to share, to let him in, but I couldn’t betray my client’s trust. The conversation hung in the air, and I felt the tension between the woman he loved and the lawyer I had to be.
